{{Infobox non test cricket team | country_name = Ireland | image_file = Cricket Ireland Logo.png | image_caption = Cricket Ireland Logo. | icc_member_year = 1993 | icc_status = Associate with ODI status | icc_region = Europe | WCL_division = One | regional_tournament = European Cricket Championship | regional_tournament_division = One | current_captain = [[William Porterfield]] | current_coach = [[Phil Simmons]] | manager = [[Roy Torrens]] | first_match = 10 September 1855 v Gentlemen of England at [[Dublin]] | world_ranking = 11th | regional_ranking = 1st | odi_matches = 70 | odi_win_loss_record = 32/34 (1 Tied/3 NR)<ref>{{citation |url=http://stats.cricinfo.com/ireland/engine/records/team/results_summary.html?class=2;id=29;type=team |title=Ireland / Records / One-Day Internationals / Result summary |publisher=Cricinfo}} Retrieved on 20 Sept 2011.</ref> | t20i_matches = 17 | t20i_win_loss_record = 7/8 (2 NR)<ref>{{citation |url=http://stats.cricinfo.com/ci/engine/records/team/results_summary.html?class=3;id=29;type=team |title=Records: Twenty20 Internationals: Ireland |publisher=Cricinfo}} Retrieved on 1 July 2010.</ref> | fc_matches = 141 | fc_win_loss_record = 38/41 | la_matches = 155 | la_win_loss_record = 41/94 | icc_world_cup_qualifier_apps = 5 | icc_world_cup_qualifier_first = [[1994 ICC Trophy|1994]] | icc_world_cup_qualifier_best = Won, [[2009 ICC World Cup Qualifier|2009]] | cricket_world_cup_apps = 2 | cricket_world_cup_first = [[2007 Cricket World Cup|2007]] | cricket_world_cup_best = 8th | asofdate = 14 July 2011 }}
The '''Ireland cricket team''' is the [[cricket]] team representing all of [[Ireland]]. Because of political difficulties, the [[Irish Cricket Union]] (ICU) was not elected to the [[International Cricket Council]] (ICC) until 1993, and qualified for the [[Cricket World Cup|World Cup]] for the first time in 2007. The Irish Cricket Union is the governing body of Irish cricket. The Irish cricket team is made up of both professional cricketers and those who earn their living outside the sport. [[Cricket Ireland]], which succeeded the Irish Cricket Union as the sport's governing body in the country, introduced contracts for its players in 2009,<ref>http://www.cricketeurope4.net/DATABASE/ARTICLES2/articles/000072/007219.shtml</ref> and as of the [[2011 Cricket World Cup]] 13 players have full-time contracts.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.espncricinfo.com/icc_cricket_worldcup2011/content/current/story/504058.html |title=Johnston says Ireland not ready for Tests |first=Brydon |last=Coverdale |publisher=[[ESPNcricinfo]] |date=3 March 2011 |accessdate=3 March 2011}}</ref>
The first match played by an Irish team was in 1855. Since then, Ireland have gained a reputation for [[giant-killing]]. Ireland played their first [[One Day International]] (ODI) in 2006 against England. Since then, they have gone on to play 61 ODIs, resulting in 29 victories, 28 defeats, 3 [[Result (cricket)#No result|no results]], and 1 [[tie (draw)|tie]].<ref>{{Citation |url=http://www.cricketarchive.com/Archive/Records/Ireland/Odis/Playing_Record.html |title=Ireland Playing Record in ODI Matches |publisher=CricketArchive}} Retrieved on 2 March 2011.</ref> Highlights in Ireland's cricketing history include beating a touring West Indies side in 1928, 1969, and again in 2004, progressing to the second round of the 2007 World Cup â in which they beat Pakistan and Bangladesh and tied with Zimbabwe â and beating England in the 2011 World Cup.
Ireland take part in the [[ICC Trophy]], the [[European Cricket Championship]] (which they have won three times and hold the title of European champions), and the [[ICC Intercontinental Cup]], which they have won consecutively three times since 2005. Until 2009, the team also competed in the [[Friends Provident Trophy]] against English counties. Ireland is an [[List of International Cricket Council members#Associate Members|Associate member]] of the ICC; Associates are the next level of team below those that play [[Test cricket]]. Due to their recent successes in the Intercontinental Cup and at the World Cup, they have been labelled the "leading Associate".<ref>{{citation |url=http://content-uk.cricinfo.com/tri-kenya/content/story/374302.html |title=Zimbabwe should avoid another banana skin |author=Martin Williamson |publisher=Cricinfo |date=17 October 2008}} Retrieved on 3 November 2008.</ref> Ireland is currently one of the teams in [[2007 ICC World Cricket League Division One|Division 1]] of [[List of International Cricket Council members#Associate Members|Associate Members]] of [[International Cricket Council]] who has [[One Day International]] and [[Twenty20|T20]] International status. After the tremendous success at International stage , Cricket Ireland has applied for [[List of International Cricket Council members#Full Members|Full Membership]] from the [[International Cricket Council]]. Ireland have recently won the [[ICC World Twenty20 Qualifier 2008]] and [[2009 ICC World Cup Qualifier]] and qualified for [[2009 World Twenty20]] and [[2011 Cricket World Cup]]. Being a full member will allow Ireland to become a permanent [[One Day International]] playing nation and eventually grant them [[Test Cricket|Test]] status.<ref>http://www.cricinfo.com/ireland/content/current/story/432837.html</ref>
==History== ===Early history=== Cricket was introduced to Ireland by the English in the towns of [[Kilkenny]] and [[Ballinasloe]] in the early 19th century. In the 1830s, the game began to spread; many of the clubs which were founded in the following 30 years are still in existence today.<ref name="cricinfo history">{{citation |url=http://www.cricinfo.com/db/NATIONAL/ICC_MEMBERS/IRELAND/HISTORY.html |title=A brief history of cricket: Cricket in Ireland |publisher=Cricinfo}} Retrieved on 3 November 2008.</ref> The first Irish national team played in 1855 against The Gentlemen of England in Dublin. In the 1850s, the Englishman Charles Lawrence was responsible for developing the game in Ireland through his coaching.<ref name="cricinfo history"/> In the 1850s and 1860s, Ireland was visited for the first time by touring professional teams. Ireland's first match against [[Marylebone Cricket Club]] (the M.C.C.) was in 1858.<ref name="cricinfo history"/>
The game increased in popularity until the early 1880s. The land war in the 1880s resulting from the [[Irish Land Commission]] and a ban on playing "foreign" games by the [[Gaelic Athletic Association]] set back the spread of cricket. The ban was not lifted until 1970.<ref name="cricinfo history"/> Anyone playing foreign games such as cricket would be banned from the extremely popular Irish games such as [[hurling]] and [[Gaelic football]].<ref name="cricinfo history"/> Irish teams toured Canada and the USA in 1879, 1888, 1892, and 1909. On top of this, Ireland defeated a touring South African side in 1904.<ref name="cricinfo history"/> Their first match with [[First-class cricket|first-class]] status was played on 19 May 1902 against a London County side including [[W.G. Grace]]. The Irish, captained by [[Sir Tim O'Brien, 3rd Baronet|Sir Tim O'Brien]], won convincingly by [[The result in cricket|238 runs]].<ref>{{citation |url=http://www.cricketarchive.co.uk/Archive/Scorecards/5/5899.html |title=f5558: London County v Ireland: Ireland in England 1902 |publisher=CricketArchive.com}} Retrieved on 5 November 2008.</ref>
===Before 1993=== After the 1902 tour of England, where four matches yielded one win, two draws and one loss, the Irish did not play first-class cricket again for five years.<ref>{{citation |url=http://www.cricketarchive.com/Archive/Seasons/ENG/1902_ENG_Ireland_in_England_1902.html |title=Ireland in England 1902 |publisher=CricketArchive.com}} Retrieved on 11 November 2008.</ref> Although the Irish had lost to the South Africans in 1894 â Ireland's first match against a Test-playing nation â Ireland defeated South Africa in 1904; it was the team's first victory against a Test side.<ref name="Irish timeline">{{citation |url=http://www.cricketeurope4.net/CRICKETEUROPE/GENERAL/TIMELINES/ireland.shtml |title=A Timeline of Irish Cricket |publisher=CricketEurope4.net}} Retrieved on 11 November 2008.</ref> In 1909, the first annual first-class match between Ireland and [[Scotland cricket team|Scotland]] was held. An annual match against the M.C.C. was arranged and held from 1924 onwards.<ref name="cricinfo history"/>
The Irish played yearly first-class games with the Scots, only interrupted by wars, up until 1999, but all their other cricket was dictated by whenever touring international sides found it convenient to visit Ireland. However, they sometimes surprised [[Test cricket|Test]] nations in these games, winning by 60 runs in a three-day game in [[Dublin]] over the [[West Indian cricket team|West Indies]] in 1928, for example; it was Ireland's first match against the West Indies.<ref name="Irish timeline"/> In 1969, they defeated a West Indian side including [[Clive Lloyd]] and [[Clyde Walcott]] by nine wickets, after bowling them out for 25. The match was played at [[Sion Mills]] in [[County Tyrone]].<ref>{{citation |url=http://www.cricketarchive.com/Archive/Scorecards/30/30223.html |title=misc3695 Ireland v West Indians: West Indies in British Isles 1969 |publisher=CricketArchive.com}} Retrieved on 16 November 2008.</ref> This was the last time Ireland defeated a touring side until 2003 when they beat Zimbabwe by 10 wickets.<ref>{{citation |url=http://content-uk.cricinfo.com/ci/content/story/129584.html |title=Ireland overwhelm Zimbabwe in ten-wicket win |publisher=Cricinfo |date=2003-06-13 |accessdate=2008-05-28}}</ref>
The Scots and the Irish were mostly competing with [[Sri Lankan cricket team|Sri Lanka]] for the title as best non-Test nation at the time â indeed, Ireland drew with Sri Lanka in a rain-hit first-class match in 1979, Ireland scoring a total of 341/7 in two innings while Sri Lanka made 288/6 in one innings. Ireland joined the ICC as an [[List of International Cricket Council members#Associate Members|Associate member]] in 1993, a year before Scotland.<ref>{{citation |url=http://icc-cricket.yahoo.com/about-icc/history-1989-present.html |title=1989 â present â International Cricket Council |publisher=ICC-cricket.yahoo.com}} Retrieved on 10 November 2008.</ref>
===ICC Trophy=== As a member of the ICC in 1994, Ireland were allowed to compete in the [[ICC Trophy]] for the first time. They won three of their seven games to finish seventh in the tournament.<ref>{{citation |url=http://www.cricketarchive.com/Archive/Events/Tables/ABN-AMRO_ICC_Trophy_1993-94.html |title=ABN-AMRO ICC Trophy 1993/94 points table |publisher=CricketArchive.com}} Retrieved on 12 November 2008.</ref> Three years later in [[Malaysia]], they progressed to the semi-finals after a good showing in the group stage,<ref>{{citation |url=http://www.cricketarchive.com/Archive/Events/Tables/Carlsberg_ICC_Trophy_1996-97.html |title=Carlsberg ICC Trophy 1996/97 points table |publisher=CricketArchive.com}} Retrieved on 12 November 2008.</ref> but lost by seven runs to Kenya.<ref>{{citation |url=http://www.cricketarchive.com/Archive/Scorecards/63/63787.html |title=icct345 Ireland v Kenya: Carlsberg ICC Trophy 1996/97 (Semi-Final) |publisher=CricketArchive.com}} Retrieved on 12 November 2008.</ref> They went on to lose the third place play-off with Scotland, thus missing a place at the [[1999 cricket World Cup]]. The 2001 tournament in Canada showed the batting skills of [[Ed Joyce]], who ended up with 359 runs at an [[Batting average#Batting average in cricket|average]] of 71.80 in eight innings with a highest score of 87.<ref>{{citation |url=http://www.cricketeurope4.net/CRICKETEUROPE/DATABASE/2001/TOURNAMENTS/ICCTROPHY/statistics.shtml |title=ICC Trophy 2001: Tournament Statistics |publisher=CricketEurope4.net}} Retrieved on 11 November 2008.</ref> Joyce, who had been signed by [[Middlesex County Cricket Club|Middlesex]] two years earlier, could not save the team from a number of defeats, however. They lost to the [[United States cricket team|USA]] by six wickets in the first match in Canada, and also lost to [[Danish cricket team|Denmark]] by 12 runs. In the end, the Irish lost five matches, finishing eighth in the tournament.<ref>{{citation |url=http://www.cricketeurope4.net/CRICKETEUROPE/DATABASE/2001/TOURNAMENTS/ICCTROPHY/about.shtml |title=ICC Trophy 2001: Results |publisher=CricketEurope4.net}} Retrieved on 11 November 2008.</ref>
The [[2005 ICC Trophy]], which was hosted in Ireland â the group stages in [[Belfast]], [[Northern Ireland]], the final stages in [[Dublin]], [[Republic of Ireland]] â saw the Irish improve drastically. Ed Joyce's four years in [[county cricket]], where he earlier in 2005 became the first batsman to hit 1,000 runs, gave him the experience to lift the Irish to big totals (he [[Batting average#Batting average in cricket|averaged]] 106 in four innings for Ireland), and even when he left for [[County Championship]] games with [[Middlesex County Cricket Club|Middlesex]], they managed to win, defeating [[Canadian cricket team|Canada]] by four-wickets thanks to [[Peter Gillespie]], who hit a career highest score in the ICC Trophy with 64 not out â his first fifty â to anchor their chase to 239. Earlier, South African-born [[Andre Botha (cricketer)|Andre Botha]] had taken 4/47 runs.<ref>{{citation |url=http://www.cricketarchive.com/Archive/Seasons/IRELAND/2005_IRELAND_ICC_Trophy_2005.html |title=ICC Trophy 2005 |publisher=CricketEurope4.net}} Retrieved on 12 November 2008.</ref> In the final against Scotland, as they conceded a total of 324/9 after electing to bowl first. The return of Joyce did not help; even though he made 81 the Irish still lost the match by 47 runs.<ref>{{citation |url=http://content-uk.cricinfo.com/icct/content/story/213443.html |title=Elementary for Watson as Scotland secure Trophy |author=Edward Craig |publisher=Cricinfo |date=13 July 2005}} Retrieved on 3 November 2008.</ref> Joyce later that year qualified to play for [[English Cricket Team|England]], leaving the Irish cricket team. He is still hailed as one of the best players ever produced by Ireland.<ref>{{citation |url=http://content-www.cricinfo.com/magazine/content/story/286433.html |title=Fuelled by team spirit |author=Dileep Premachandran |publisher=Cricinfo |date=21 March 2007}} Retrieved on 12 November 2008.</ref> Although Ireland lost in the final, they had secured their place at the 2007 World Cup as well as an extra $500,000 over the next four years from the ICC to encourage development of Irish cricket.<ref name="Edward Craig">{{citation |url=http://content-uk.cricinfo.com/icct/content/story/213344.html |title=Scotland begin as slight favourites |author=Edward Craig |publisher=Cricinfo |date=12 July 2005}} Retrieved on 3 November 2008.</ref>
===Intercontinental Cup=== With the introduction of the [[ICC Intercontinental Cup]] in 2004,<ref>{{citation |url=http://icc-cricket.yahoo.com/icc-events/intercontinental-cup.html |title=ICC Intercontinental Cup |publisher=ICC-cricket.yahoo.com}} Retrieved on 23 July 2008</ref> Ireland received a chance to play first-class on a regular basis. The competition was split into four divisions, with the top team from each division progressing to a knock-out stage. Whilst they beat the [[Netherlands cricket team|Netherlands]], Ireland lost their group match against Scotland in [[2004 ICC Intercontinental Cup|2004]] and failed to progress beyond the group stage.<ref>{{citation |url=http://uk.cricinfo.com/db/ARCHIVE/2004/OTHERS/ICC-CONT/ICC-CONT_POINTS.html |title=Intercontinental Cup 2004 points table |publisher=Cricinfo |year=2004}} Retrieved on 11 November 2008.</ref> Ireland won their first Cup title in [[2005 ICC Intercontinental Cup|October 2005]] with a six wicket win over Kenya. An unbeaten century by [[Niall O'Brien (cricketer)|Niall O'Brien]], half centuries from [[Eoin Morgan]], [[Andre Botha (cricketer)|Andre Botha]], and [[Jeremy Bray]], along with four wickets each for [[Andrew White (cricketer)|Andrew White]] and [[Kyle McCallan]] were the principal contributions.<ref>{{citation |url=http://content-uk.cricinfo.com/icccont/content/story/223519.html |title=Ireland secure Intercontinental glory |publisher=Cricinfo |date=29 October 2005}} Retrieved on 11 November 2008.</ref> For its third edition, the tournament was revamped. The number of participating teams was reduced from 16 to 8 and was divided into two groups in stead of four. This was done to ensure that the best Associate sides got the chance to play more first-class cricket and develop.<ref>{{citation |url=http://content-uk.cricinfo.com/icccont/content/story/227844.html |title=Intercontinental Cup to become truly global |date=30 November 2005}} Retrieved on 11 November 2008.</ref> In May 2007, Ireland played in the final of the [[ICC Intercontinental Cup]] against Canada. Ireland, led by [[Trent Johnston]], emerged convincing winners by an innings and 115 runs at Grace Road, the four-day match concluding within two days. This made Ireland the first team to successfully defend the Continental Cup, confirming its current status as the most successful non-Test playing nation.<ref>{{citation |url=http://content-uk.cricinfo.com/icccont/content/story/295595.html |title=Ireland complete final rout |date=23 May 2007}} Retrieved on 10 November 2008.</ref>
===English county competition=== [[Image:100 1795 (2).jpg|right|thumbnail|right|Ireland compete against [[Essex County Cricket Club|Essex]] at [[Clontarf Cricket Club Ground|Castle Avenue]].]] Ireland, along with Scotland and the Netherlands, has at times played in competitions for [[List of English First Class Cricket Counties|English county cricket sides]], including the [[Benson & Hedges Cup]] and the [[Friends Provident Trophy]] (previously the [[C&G Trophy]]). Since there is no nationality restriction in county cricket, non-Irish players have competed for Ireland in these matches. For example [[Hansie Cronje]] of South Africa competed for Ireland in the 1997 Benson & Hedges Cup,<ref>{{citation |url=http://cricketarchive.com/Archive/Players/2/2009/2009.html |title=Hanse Cronje |publisher=CricketArchive.com}} Retrieved on 10 November 2008.</ref> and more recently New Zealander [[Jesse Ryder]] played for Ireland in 2007.<ref>{{citation |url=http://content-uk.cricinfo.com/newzealand/content/story/296125.html |title=Ryder no-show for Ireland |date=28 May 2007 |publisher=Cricinfo}} Retrieved on 10 November 2008.</ref> In 2004, Ireland beat [[Surrey County Cricket Club|Surrey]] by five wickets in the C&G Trophy.<ref>{{citation |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/cricket/4500887.stm |title=Last chance for the giant-killers |date=30 April 2005 |publisher=BBC Online | accessdate=5 January 2010}} Retrieved on 10 November 2008.</ref>
For the 2006 season, the C&G Trophy was reorganised to include a round-robin stage instead of being entirely knock-out. Whereas Ireland had only one match guaranteed in the tournament before, they now had more fixtures against English county sides. For the 2006 tournament, they were bolstered by the signings of [[Saqlain Mushtaq]] and [[Shahid Afridi]], the two overseas players they were allowed when competing in English domestic competitions. Ireland recorded one win in their nine matches.<ref>{{citation |url=http://uk.cricinfo.com/db/ARCHIVE/2006/ENG_LOCAL/C+G/C+G_2006_TABLE.html |title=Cheltenham & Gloucester Trophy â Points Table |year=2006 |publisher=Cricinfo}} Retrieved on 10 November 2008.</ref> Their victory was over [[Gloucestershire County Cricket Club|Gloucestershire]] on 30 April by 47 runs.<ref>{{citation |url=http://content-uk.cricinfo.com/ireland/content/story/245844.html |title=Ireland spin their way to upset |date=30 April 2006 |publisher=Cricinfo}} Retrieved on 10 November 2008.</ref>
The C&G Trophy changed its name to Friends Provident Trophy for the 2007 season. In 2007, Ireland played in the Friends Provident Trophy against nine English county sides. Of those nine matches, they lost six and the remaining three matches were abandoned due to rain. They finished bottom in the South Conference of the trophy.<ref>{{citation |url=http://content-uk.cricinfo.com/countycricket2007/engine/series/268020.html?view=pointstable |title=Friends Provident Trophy, 2007 |year=2007 |publisher=Cricinfo}} Retrieved on 10 November 2008.</ref>
For the 2008 season, the round-robin section of the trophy was changed from two divisions to three; Ireland were in the newly formed Midlands Division. In 2008, Ireland played eight games in the Midlands Division, winning one match with one no result and six losses. They finished fifth in the division which had five teams.<ref>{{citation |url=http://content-uk.cricinfo.com/countycricket2008/engine/series/319688.html?view=pointstable |title=Friends Provident Trophy, 2008 |year=2008 |publisher=Cricinfo}} Retrieved on 10 November 2008.</ref> Ireland's four wicket victory over [[Warwickshire County Cricket Club|Warwickshire]] on 16 May was Ireland's first win in the competition against a county side for two years.<ref>{{citation |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/cricket/counties/7405774.stm |title=Porterfield leads Ireland to win |date=16 May 2008 |publisher=BBC Online | accessdate=5 January 2010}} Retrieved on 10 November 2008.</ref> Captain William Porterfield anchored the innings with 69 runs.<ref>{{citation |url=http://content-uk.cricinfo.com/ireland/content/story/351199.html |title=Porterfield helps down Warwickshire |date=16 May 2008 |publisher=Cricinfo}} Retrieved on 10 November 2008.</ref>
In 2009, Ireland inflicted [[Worcestershire County Cricket Club|Worcestershire's]] lowest ever one-day total (58 all out) in a 94-run Friends Provident Trophy group A win at New Road. [[Peter Connell]] did the most damage in taking 5â19. It was the first time that Ireland had bowled out a county for less than a hundred. This was Ireland only win in the group & they finished 5th & last with 4.0 pts.<ref>{{citation |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport2/hi/cricket/counties/8054602.stm. | work=BBC News | date=20 May 2009 | accessdate=5 January 2010 | title=Connell haul sinks Worcestershire}}</ref> After the 2009 competition the [[English Cricket Board]] reorganised it, changing the format from 50 to 40 overs. Although Ireland were invited to participate the team declined, preferring to focus their limited financial resources on international cricket.<ref>{{citation |url=http://www.espncricinfo.com/ireland/content/story/427110.html |title=Ireland decline ECB's 40-over invite |publisher=Cricinfo |date=28 September 2009}} Retrieved on 15 March 2011.</ref>
===One Day Internationals before 2007=== As a result of their second place in the 2005 ICC Trophy, Ireland qualified for the 2007 World Cup and gained official ODI status until 2009.<ref name="Edward Craig"/> Ireland's inaugural ODI was played in Belfast at the [[Civil Service Cricket Club]], [[Stormont, Belfast|Stormont]], on 13 June 2006 against England. It was the first time Ireland had played the full England side. Tickets sold well for the game, with a full house of 7,500 attendees. [[Marcus Trescothick]] scored a century as England, scoring 301/7 from their 50 overs, beat Ireland who made 263/9 from their allotment, including 52 from Andre Botha, the highest score of the Irish innings. [[Andrew Strauss]], England's stand-in captain for the match, said "I thought [Ireland] played really well, and put us under pressure... Full credit to Ireland though who played really well, and showed what they're capable of".<ref>{{citation |url=http://content-uk.cricinfo.com/ireland/content/story/249849.html |title=Ireland announce squad for England match |publisher=Cricinfo |date=7 June 2006}} Retrieved on 3 November 2008..</ref><ref>{{citation |url=http://content-uk.cricinfo.com/england/content/story/250291.html |title=England's win fails to hide cracks |author=Will Luke |publisher=Cricinfo |date=13 June 2006}} Retrieved on 3 November 2008.</ref>
August saw them participate in Division One of the European Championship, against Denmark, [[Italian cricket team|Italy]], the Netherlands and Scotland. The games against the Netherlands and Scotland had ODI status. In the tournament, and what was the team's second ODI, Ireland recorded their first ODI win, beating fellow Associates Scotland by 85 runs after man-of-the-match Eoin Morgan made 99.<ref>{{citation |url=http://content-uk.cricinfo.com/scotland/content/story/255696.html |title=Morgan stars as Ireland shock Scotland |publisher=Cricinfo |date=6 August 2006}} Retrieved on 10 November 2008.</ref><ref>{{citation |url=http://www.cricketarchive.com/Archive/Records/Ireland/Odis/Odi_List.html |title=List of Ireland ODI Matches |publisher=CricketArchive.com}} Retrieved on 10 November 2008.</ref> Although the match against the Netherlands was a no-result, Ireland won the European Championship title.<ref>{{citation |url=http://content-uk.cricinfo.com/ireland/content/story/256045.html |title=Ireland secure European title |publisher=Cricinfo |date=9 August 2006}} Retrieved on 10 November 2008.</ref>
==One Day Internationals status (2007â present)== ===2007 World Cup=== In August 2006, the Irish Cricket Union named their squad for the [[2007 Cricket World Cup|2007 World Cup]].<ref>{{citation |url=http://content-usa.cricinfo.com/ci/content/story/257736.html?CMP=OTC-RSS |title=Ireland name World Cup squad |date=25 August 2006 |publisher=Cricinfo}} Retrieved on 10 November 2008.</ref> January 2007 saw the start of more than three months of almost constant cricket. First was a visit to Kenya, where they took part in [[2007 ICC World Cricket League Division One|Division One]] of the [[ICC World Cricket League]]. They finished fifth in the league after four narrow defeats and Kenya won the league.<ref>{{citation |url=http://content-uk.cricinfo.com/magazine/content/story/279633.html |title=Life is good beyond the Test world |author=Martin Williamson |publisher=Cricinfo |date=9 February 2007}} Retrieved 10 November 2008.</ref> Prior to the World Cup, the team participated in a high-performance camp in South Africa.<ref name="tough at the top">{{citation |url=http://content-uk.cricinfo.com/ireland/content/story/308932.html |title=Tough at the top |publisher=Cricinfo |author=Andrew McGlashan |date=1 September 2007}} Retrieved 10 November 2008.</ref> The team was managed by [[Roy Torrens]]. In the final 13-a-side warm-up matches before the World Cup, Ireland lost to [[South African cricket team|South Africa]] by 34 runs;<ref>{{citation |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/cricket/6420925.stm |title=Ireland make South Africa sweat |publisher=BBC Online |date=5 March 2007 | accessdate=5 January 2010}} Retrieved 5 November 2008.</ref> and beat Canada by seven wickets.<ref>{{citation |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/cricket/6431569.stm |title=Irish thrash Canada in Trinidad |publisher=BBC Online |date=8 March 2007 | accessdate=5 January 2010}} Retrieved 5 November 2008.</ref> Ireland's performance in their inaugural World Cup in the [[2007 Cricket World Cup|2007 tournament]] took many pundits by surprise. Their first game was on 15 March when they tied with [[Zimbabwean cricket team|Zimbabwe]], primarily thanks to Ireland's first ever World Cup century by man-of-the-match [[Jeremy Bray (cricketer)|Jeremy Bray]] and economical bowling in the final overs by Trent Johnston and Andre Botha. From having required 15 runs from the last six overs with four wickets in hand, Zimbabwe were dismissed for 221 off the last ball of the innings with the scores level.<ref>{{citation |url=http://content-uk.cricinfo.com/wc2007/content/story/285484.html |title=Bray makes it Ireland's day |publisher=Cricinfo |author=S Rajesh and HR Gopalakrishna |date=15 March 2007}} Retrieved 5 November 2008.</ref> In their second match, played on [[Saint Patrick's Day]], they beat the fourth-ranked team in the world, [[Pakistani cricket team|Pakistan]], by three wickets, thus knocking Pakistan out of the competition.<ref>{{citation |url=http://content-uk.cricinfo.com/wc2007/content/story/285827.html |title=Shamrocks turn Pakistan green |publisher=Cricinfo |author=Dileep Premachandran |date=17 March 2007}} Retrieved 5 November 2008.</ref> These two results were sufficient to advance Ireland to the Super 8 stage of the tournament. Their final group stage game was against the West Indies, where they lost by eight wickets.<ref>{{citation |url=http://content-uk.cricinfo.com/wc2007/content/story/286885.html |title=Chanderpaul hundred sinks Ireland |publisher=Cricinfo |author=Will Luke |date=23 March 2007}} Retrieved 5 November 2008.</ref>
In the Super 8 stage, they lost their first four matches against England, South Africa, New Zealand and Australia, but then recorded a 74-run victory against the 9th ranked team in the world and Test playing nation [[Bangladesh national cricket team|Bangladesh]]. As this was their second win against a full ICC member, Ireland gained promotion by way of recognition in the ICC's official one-day rankings. The list consisted of the ten full members, Kenya, and Ireland. Ireland suffered defeat in their final match of the tournament. The team received a heroes welcome on 24 April 2007 in Dublin.<ref>{{citation |url=http://www.irishtimes.com/sports/other/2007/0424/1177280191377.html |title=Irish team receive a heroes welcome |publisher=''[[The Irish Times]]'' |date=24 April 2007}} Retrieved on 10 November 2008.</ref> A documentary, ''Breaking Boundaries'' directed by Paul Davey recounting the story of the World Cup campaign was released in 2008.<ref name='fillum'>{{Citation|url=http://www.zanzibarfilms.net/documentaries_tv/the_breaking_boundaries.html |title=Breaking Boundaries |accessdate=2009-06-03 |publisher=Zanzibar Films}}</ref>
===After the World Cup (2007â2008)=== After the World Cup, former West Indies cricketer [[Phil Simmons]] took over the role of coach from [[Adrian Birrell]].<ref>{{citation |url=http://content-uk.cricinfo.com/ireland/content/story/281572.html |title=Simmons confirmed as new Irish coach |publisher=Cricinfo |date=25 February 2007}} Retrieved 5 November 2008.</ref> [[Indian cricket team|India]] were scheduled to play [[South African cricket team|South Africa]] in a series of One Day Internationals in Ireland in June 2007. Ireland also played one-off matches at Stormont against the two teams. Missing several players from their World Cup squad, Ireland lost both games.<ref>{{citation |url=http://content-uk.cricinfo.com/engvind/engine/series/258449.html |title=Matches India tour of Ireland, England and Scotland, JunâSep 2007 |publisher=Cricinfo}} Retrieved on 16 November 2008.</ref> Ireland hosted a [[Quadrangular Series in Ireland in 2007|quadrangular tournament in Dublin and Belfast]] from 10 July to 15 July involving the West Indies, the Netherlands, and Scotland. Ireland and the West Indies both won two games with their direct encounter being a [[The result in cricket#No result|no result]] due to rain. The West Indies were declared tournament winners because of a bonus point won against the Netherlands.<ref>{{citation |url=http://content-uk.cricinfo.com/4natireland/content/story/302095.html |title=Ireland win but West Indies take series |publisher=Cricinfo |date=15 July 2007}} Retrieved 10 November 2008.</ref> Ireland played three ODIs against Test nations (two losses and a no result), and five ODIs in total, winning the two matches against fellow Associates Scotland and the Netherlands. A triangular ODI series in Scotland as well as the European Twenty20 Championship had to be cancelled due to conflicting dates with the quadrangular series.<ref>{{citation |url=http://content-http://content-www.cricinfo.com/other/content/story/294561.html |title=Inaugural European Twenty20 tournament cancelled |publisher=Cricinfo |date=17 May 2007}} Retrieved on 10 November 2008.</ref> The [[2007â08 ICC Intercontinental Cup]] began in June, with Ireland playing their first match in August. In November 2008, the team's campaign drew to a conclusion. After having finished second in the round-robin stage of the competition, Ireland faced [[Namibia cricket team|Namibia]] in the final. Ireland won by nine wickets under the captaincy of [[William Porterfield]], securing their third consecutive Intercontinental Cup title.<ref>{{citation |url=http://content-uk.cricinfo.com/icccont2007/content/story/376686.html |title=Niall O'Brien century pilots Ireland to title |publisher=Cricinfo |date=2 November 2008}} Retrieved on 3 November 2008.</ref> In March 2008 Ireland toured [[Bangladesh]], playing three ODIs against the hosts and losing all of them.<ref>{{citation |url=http://www.cricinfo.com/db/ARCHIVE/2007-08/IRELAND_IN_BDESH/ |title=Bangladesh v Ireland 2007â08 |publisher=Cricinfo |date=April 2008}} Retrieved on 10 November 2008.</ref> In July, Ireland played a [[2008 Associates Tri-Series in Scotland|tri-series]] against New Zealand and Scotland in [[Aberdeen]] and lost both matches.<ref>{{citation |url=http://uk.cricinfo.com/db/ARCHIVE/2008/OD_TOURNEYS/3-NAT_SCOT/ |title=Associates Tri-Series (in Scotland) |publisher=Cricinfo}} Retrieved on 4 November 2008.</ref>
Reigning champions Ireland hosted the [[European Cricket Championship]] (Division One) in late July and they won their third European title, winning every game, including the decisive encounter against Scotland by seven wickets. They were captained by William Porterfield.<ref>{{citation |url=http://content-uk.cricinfo.com/ci-icc/content/story/363165.html |title=Ireland retain European title |publisher=Cricinfo |date=31 July 2008}} Retrieved on 4 November 2008.</ref> In early August, Ireland hosted five other Associate nations at the [[2009 ICC World Twenty20 Qualifier]] in Belfast. During the tournament, Ireland made their [[Twenty20 International]] debut. Playing against Scotland, they won a low scoring match by four wickets.<ref>{{citation |url=http://www.cricinfo.com/iccworldtwenty20/content/story/363426.html |title=Botha shines in Ireland win |author=John Ward |publisher=Cricinfo |date=2 August 2008}} Retrieved on 11 June 2009.</ref> After beating Bermuda in their second and final match of the group stages,<ref>{{citation |url=http://www.cricinfo.com/iccworldtwenty20/content/story/363550.html |title=Ireland clinch tight match against Bermuda |author=John Ward |publisher=Cricinfo |date=3 August 2008}} Retrieved on 11 June 2009.</ref> Ireland progressed to the knock-out round of the tournament. Ireland defeated Kenya in the semi-finals to secure a place in the final against the Netherlands.<ref>{{citation |url=http://www.cricinfo.com/iccworldtwenty20/content/story/363626.html |title=Ireland inch past Kenya into final |author=John Ward |publisher=Cricinfo |date=4 August 2008}} Retrieved on 11 June 2009.</ref> The final was rained off and the teams shared the trophy.<ref>{{citation |url=http://www.cricinfo.com/iccworldtwenty20/content/story/363767.html |title=Ireland and Netherlands share the trophy |publisher=Cricinfo |date=5 August 2008}} Retrieved on 11 June 2009.</ref> Andre Botha was named the Man of the Tournament.<ref>{{citation |url=http://cricketarchive.com/Archive/Seasons/IRELAND/2008_IRELAND_ICC_World_Twenty20_Qualifier_2008.html |title=ICC World Twenty20 Qualifier 2008 |publisher=CricketArchive.com}} Retrieved on 11 June 2009.</ref> By getting to the final of the tournament, Ireland qualified for the [[2009 ICC World Twenty20]] in England in June 2009. Later in August, Ireland played three ODIs at home against Kenya. Ireland won the first game, the second game could not be finished due to rain and the last match was completely washed out.<ref>{{citation |url=http://content-uk.cricinfo.com/ireland/content/story/366435.html |title=Ireland take series after washout |publisher=Cricinfo |date=27 August 2008}} Retrieved on 3 November 2008.</ref> In October, the team visited Kenya for a [[2008 Associates Tri-Series in Kenya|tri-series of ODIs]] with the hosts and Zimbabwe. Only two of Ireland's four games in the round-robin stage could be played, the others were rained off. Ireland suffered defeat in their first match to Zimbabwe,<ref>{{citation |url=http://content-uk.cricinfo.com/tri-kenya/content/story/374342.html |title=Taibu and Dabengwa star in convincing Zimbabwe win |publisher=Cricinfo |date=17 October 2007}} Retrieved on 11 November 2008.</ref> but won their second against Kenya.<ref>{{citation |url=http://content-uk.cricinfo.com/tri-kenya/content/story/374480.html |title=Kevin O'Brien sets up comprehensive win |publisher=Cricinfo |date=18 October 2007}} Retrieved on 11 November 2008.</ref> Ireland failed to qualify for the final because of their run-rate, which was lower than that of both Kenya and Zimbabwe.<ref>{{citation |url=http://content-uk.cricinfo.com/tri-kenya/content/story/375086.html |title=Ireland sent packing by the rain |publisher=Cricinfo |date=25 October 2007}} Retrieved on 23 November 2008.</ref> In January 2009, Ireland dropped to 11th in the ODI rankings after Zimbabwe due to victories against Kenya.<ref>{{citation |url=http://www.espncricinfo.com/ci-icc/content/story/388418.html |title=Opportunity for Australia to reclaim top spot |publisher=Cricinfo |date=30 January 2009}} Retrieved on 15 March 2011.</ref>
===2009 and 2010 World Twenty20s=== In the run up to the 2009 ICC World Twenty20, Ireland were deprived of batsman [[Eoin Morgan]], similarly to [[Ed Joyce]] several years earlier, who was selected to play for England, making him ineligible to play for Ireland again.<ref>{{citation |url=http://www.cricinfo.com/engvwi2009/content/current/story/405314.html |title=Switching colours, switching hits |author=Andrew McGlashan |publisher=Cricinfo |date=21 May 2009}} Retrieved on 11 June 2009.</ref> Ireland played their first Twenty20 International against a full ICC member side on 8 June 2009. In their opening match of the tournament, Ireland defeated Bangladesh by four wickets and knocked them out of the tournament with Kevin and Niall O'Brien making quick runs to put Ireland back on track after their run chase wavered. It was their first victory against a full ICC Member and only their fourth Twenty20 International match.<ref>{{citation |url=http://www.cricinfo.com/wt202009/content/story/408075.html |title=Associated with the best |author=George Binoy |publisher=Cricinfo |date=8 June 2009}} Retrieved on 11 June 2009.</ref><ref>{{citation |url=http://www.cricinfo.com/wt202009/content/story/408033.html |title=Ireland storm into Super Eights |author=Jamie Alter |publisher=Cricinfo |date=8 June 2009}} Retrieved on 11 June 2009.</ref> Ireland progressed to the second stage of the competition. They were grouped with [[New Zealand national cricket team|New Zealand]], [[Pakistan national cricket team|Pakistan]] and [[Sri Lanka national cricket team|Sri Lanka]] and lost all three of their matches. In 2009, Ireland played nine ODIs, winning the seven they played against Associate nations, losing their only match against a Test team (England), and one match was abandoned.<ref>{{citation |url=http://stats.espncricinfo.com/ireland/engine/records/team/match_results.html?class=2;id=2009;team=29;type=year |title=2009 â Ireland / Records / One-Day Internationals / Match results (2009) |publisher=Cricinfo}} Retrieved on 15 March 2011.</ref>
Ireland played 17 one day internationals in 2010, winning 11 and losing 6 including beating Bangladesh and losing against number 1 ranked side Australia and other teams with Test status West Indies, Bangladesh, and Zimbabwe.<ref>{{citation |url=http://stats.espncricinfo.com/ireland/engine/records/team/match_results.html?class=2;id=2010;team=29;type=year |title=2009 â Ireland / Records / One-Day Internationals / Match results (2010) |publisher=Cricinfo}} Retrieved on 15 March 2011.</ref> Ireland were knocked out of the [[2010 ICC World Twenty20]], hosted by South Africa in April and May, after being beaten by the [[West Indies cricket team|West Indies]] they took on [[England cricket team|England]]. After 20 overs England finished on 120â8, however Ireland only managed 14â1 when the game was rained off after 3.3 overs resulting in England progressing to the super eight stage by net run rate and then to be champions.
===2011 World Cup=== Ireland beat [[England cricket team|England]] by 3 wickets on 2 March 2011 at the [[2011 Cricket World Cup|World Cup]] with [[Kevin O'Brien (cricketer)|Kevin O'Brien]] hitting the fastest World Cup century off only 50 balls.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.guardian.co.uk/sport/2011/mar/02/england-ireland-live|title=England v Ireland â as it happened|date=2011-3-2|work=Guardian|accessdate=2011-3-2|location=London|first1=Rob|last1=Smyth|first2=Alan|last2=Gardner}}</ref> It was the highest successful run chase (329 in 49.1 overs) in World Cup history.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.telegraph.co.uk/sport/cricket/cricket-world-cup/8357565/Cricket-World-Cup-2011-fastest-hundreds-in-history-of-the-competition.html|title=Cricket World Cup 2011: fastest hundreds in history of the competition|date=2011-3-2|work=Daily Telegraph|accessdate=2011-3-2|location=London|first=Ian|last=Oxborrow}}</ref><ref>{{cite web| title=Ireland vs England, ICC World Cup 2011 | url=http://iccworld-cup2011.blogspot.com/2011/03/england-vs-ireland-bangalore-2nd-march.html}}</ref> Taoiseach-in-waiting [[Enda Kenny]] congratulated the team saying "Their supreme effort will lift the spirits of every single Irish person, no matter where they are in the world."<ref>{{cite news| url=http://timesofindia.indiatimes.com/sports/cricket/cricket-world-cup-2011/news/Political-bank-woes-forgotten-as-Irish-beat-England-at-cricket/articleshow/7615954.cms#ixzz1FVc7K1Jm | work=The Times Of India | deadurl=yes}} {{Dead link|date=December 2011|bot=RjwilmsiBot}}</ref>
==Governing body== {{main|Irish Cricket Union}} The [[Irish Cricket Union]] (ICU) â the governing body of Irish cricket â was officially founded in 1923, although its predecessor had been active since 1890.<ref name="cricinfo history"/> [[File:Cricket Ireland flag.svg|250px|right|thumb|Flag of the Irish team]]In common with a number of other Ireland sporting governing bodies, the Union was formed to represent cricket throughout the island of Ireland, rather than just the [[Republic of Ireland]] and in common with its counterparts for [[Irish Rugby Football Union|rugby union]] and [[Irish Hockey Association|field hockey]], the Union therefore does not use the [[Irish tricolor]], but instead employs its own flag, which is used by such bodies as the [[International Cricket Council]] to represent the team.<ref>[http://www.cricketeurope4.net/IRISHCRICKET/index.shtml Official Cricket Ireland site showing use of flag]</ref><ref>[http://icc-cricket.yahoo.net/the-icc/icc_members/overview.php International Cricket Council official site]</ref> In 2007, it announced major changes to bring it in-line with the main cricket governing bodies.<ref name="major changes">{{citation |url=http://content-uk.cricinfo.com/ireland/content/story/314284.html |title=ICU sets out major changes |publisher=Cicinfo.com |date=8 October 2007}} Retrieved on 11 November 2008.</ref> After the World Cup, Irish cricket experienced a dip in success with poor results in the 2007 Friends Provident Trophy as many players were unavailable. The Irish cricket team was â and still is<ref>{{citation |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/cricket/counties/ireland/6651685.stm |title=Ireland consider semi-pro move |publisher=BBC Online |date=13 May 2007 | accessdate=5 January 2010}} Retrieved on 16 November 2008.</ref> â an amateur side and most of the players had full-time jobs with commitments conflicting with cricket.<ref name="tough at the top"/> After the World Cup there were delays in paying the players which resulted in them ignoring the press in protest to their treatment after an Intercontinental Cup match against Kenya.<ref name="tough at the top"/>
Warren Deutrom, the chief executive of the ICU, has stated that it wants to "seek actively to place Irish players into top-level cricket, by developing relationships with [especially] county cricket which will incorporate appropriate player release for Irish international duty, and feeder systems for developing Irish cricketers".<ref name="major changes"/> The reorganised ICU sought closer links with the English county teams, encourage the development of age group cricket, and to introduce a professional element into the Irish game. They also want to take the Ireland cricket team on winter tours more often.<ref name="major changes"/> In an attempt to prevent the game losing players to counties or other commitments such as jobs, it was suggested that central contracts should be introduced.<ref>{{citation |url=http://content-www.cricinfo.com/ireland/content/story/327056.html |title=Early promise gives way to uncertainty |author=Andrew McGlashan |publisher=Cicinfo.com |date=23 December 2007}} Retrieved on 11 November 2008.</ref> By June 2009, [[Trent Johnston]] and [[Alex Cusack]] were the only players to have central contracts with the ICU.<ref>{{citation |url=http://www.cricinfo.com/wt202009/content/story/408075.html |title=Associated with the best |author=George Binoy |publisher=Cricinfo |date=8 June 2009 |accessdate=10 June 2009}}</ref>
Deutrom has commented that it is difficult for Ireland to become a [[Test cricket|Test team]] as Ireland have not received guidance on how it can be achieved. In June 2009, shortly before the start of the 2009 ICC Twenty20 World Cup in which Ireland defeated Bangladesh to progress to the second round of the tournament, he said "Ireland has proved itself head and shoulders above the rest of the associate nations. Yet we are bumping up against a glass ceiling".<ref>{{citation |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/cricket/8081711.stm |title='Glass ceiling' frustrates Irish |publisher=BBC Online |date=3 June 2009 | accessdate=5 January 2010}} Retrieved on 9 June 2009.</ref>

==Records== {{see also|List of Ireland ODI cricketers}}
===One Day Internationals===
*Ireland have won 32 of their 70 ODIs (0.94 win/loss ratio) as of 20 Sept 2011. **W32, L34, T1, NR3 **7 wins over Scotland & 6 wins over Kenya are the most over any side. **Ireland have beaten 4 Test nations â England, Pakistan, Bangladesh (twice) and Zimbabwe. The wins against Pakistan and Bangladesh came at the [[2007 Cricket World Cup]] & the win against England came at the [[2011 Cricket World Cup]]. **Ireland's only tied ODI was against Zimbabwe, also at the 2007 World Cup. *Home record: 26 games â 13 wins, 9 losses, 2 aband., 2 n/r. **Ireland have lost only two ODIs in Dublin (to Australia, Jun '10, to England-Aug' 25 2011): 13 games â 9 wins, 2 loss, 1 aband., 1 n/r; **Whereas their record in Belfast is: 13 games â 4 wins, 7 losses, 1 aband., 1 n/r. *Highest team score: 329/7 v England, 2 March 2011 at [[M. Chinnaswamy Stadium]], [[Bangalore]], India<ref>{{citation |url=http://stats.cricinfo.com/ireland/engine/records/team/highest_innings_totals.html?class=2;id=29;type=team |title=Highest totals: Ireland â One-Day Internationals |publisher=Cricinfo}} Retrieved on 2 March 2011.</ref> *Lowest team score: 77 all out v Sri Lanka, 18 April 2007 at St. Georges, Grenada <ref>{{citation |url=http://stats.cricinfo.com/ci/engine/team/29.html?class=2;template=results;type=team;view=innings |title=Lowest totals: Ireland â One-Day Internationals |publisher=Cricinfo}} Retrieved on 4 July 2010.</ref> *Best innings bowling: 5/14, [[Trent Johnston]] v [[Canadian cricket team|Canada]], 19 April 2009 at [[SuperSport Park]], [[Centurion, Gauteng|Centurion]], [[South Africa]]<ref>{{citation |url=http://stats.cricinfo.com/ireland/engine/records/bowling/best_figures_innings.html?class=2;id=29;type=team |title=Best bowling figures in an innings: Ireland â One-Day Internationals |publisher=Cricinfo}} Retrieved on 4 July 2010.</ref> *Record Partnership Score: 227 by [[William Porterfield]] & [[Kevin O'Brien (cricketer)|Kevin O'Brien]] v Kenya, Nairobi, 2 Feb 2007.

===Twenty20 Internationals===
*Ireland have won 7 of their 17 T20Is (0.87 win/loss ratio) as off 4 July 2010. **W7, L8, NR2 **2 wins over Scotland are the most over any side. **Ireland have beaten only one Test nation, Bangledash, in T20Is, 8 June 2009. *Home record: 4 games â 3 wins, 0 losses, 0 aband., 1 n/r. **Ireland are unbeaten at home in T20Is **All 4 home T20Is were played in Belfast *Highest team score: 172/8 (20 ov.) v Canada, 3 February 2010 at Colombo (SSC), Sri Lanka<ref>{{citation |url=http://stats.cricinfo.com/ci/engine/team/29.html?class=3;orderby=team_score;template=results;type=team;view=innings |title=Highest totals: Ireland â Twenty20 Internationals |publisher=Cricinfo}} Retrieved on 4 July 2010.</ref> *Lowest team score: 14/1 (3.3 ov.) v England, 4 May 2010 at Providence, Guyana<ref>{{citation |url=http://stats.cricinfo.com/ci/engine/team/29.html?class=2;template=results;type=team;view=innings |title=Lowest totals: Ireland â Twenty20 Internationals |publisher=Cricinfo}} Retrieved on 4 July 2010.</ref> *Best innings bowling: 4/18, [[Alex Cusack]] v [[Sri Lanka cricket team|Sri Lanka]], 14 June 2009 at Lords, England<ref>{{citation |url=http://stats.cricinfo.com/ci/engine/stats/index.html?class=3;orderby=bbi;team=29;template=results;type=bowling |title=Best bowling figures in an innings: Ireland â Twenty20 Internationals |publisher=Cricinfo}} Retrieved on 4 July 2010.</ref> *Record Partnership Score: 59 by [[William Porterfield]] & [[Niall O'Brien (cricketer)|Niall O'Brien]] v Sri Lanka at Lords, England on 14 June 2009. {{col-begin}} {{col-break}} '''Most Twenty20 runs for Ireland'''<ref>{{citation |url=http://stats.cricinfo.com/ci/engine/stats/index.html?class=3;orderby=runs;team=29;template=results;type=batting |title=Most runs: Ireland â Twenty20 Internationals |publisher=Cricinfo}} Retrieved on 5 May 2010.</ref> {| class="wikitable sortable" |- style="background:#bdb76b;" !
